question: In which layer of the Sun does nuclear fusion take place?

content.source_1: The Sun’s core reaches roughly 15 million kelvin and has by far the highest pressures and densities; temperature and density fall off steeply outside the core.
content.source_2: Sustained hydrogen fusion via the proton–proton chain requires extremely high temperatures and sufficient pressure/density to keep nuclei colliding frequently.
content.source_3: Energy generated in the Sun’s deep interior is carried outward first through the radiative zone by photon diffusion and then through the convective zone to the photosphere.
content.source_4: The solar corona is the hottest layer of the Sun’s atmosphere, commonly at 1–3 million kelvin and reaching tens of millions of kelvin in intense active regions.
content.source_5: Overcoming the Coulomb barrier for nuclear fusion demands temperatures of millions of degrees; higher temperatures dramatically increase fusion reaction rates.
content.source_6: Solar flares and coronal loops in the corona heat plasma to multi‑million‑degree temperatures and release enormous amounts of energy.
